text: <@U091EBYSU|artem_zin> has left the channel
Car hacking is all the rage: <http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2016/03/fbi-cautions-motorists-to-maintain-awareness-of-automobile-hacks/>

attachments.title: FBI cautions motorists to “maintain awareness” of automobile hacks
attachments.text: Bulletin speaks to the Internet of Things' continued impact on the auto sector.
attachments.fallback: Ars Technica: FBI cautions motorists to “maintain awareness” of automobile hacks

text: <@U0DMFJC0H>: it's pretty "easy" to get into a car.
While it's almost a piece of cake to make it secure, poor developers are on the job
(Talking about opening a car solely right now, there are some immensely poor implementation)
The part that your car even has some sort of API that is accessible without direct access is just something you can't really put in practise with 100% security like anything else.
Here is the problem, from someone that is involved in hardware
PLCs and such components are notoriously hard to secure
the problem? once you make the chip, if there is a hole, it’s there
hard to update… :confused:
Yes, but I don't see why you need remote access to those things in the first place
While IoT stuff will eventually make it’s way into cars, it doesn’t make the situation better
It makes it all much worse
<@U061HDV96>: WiFi is a buzzword/selling point right now
Cars shouldn't allow for connections to be established from the outside
everything needs to have wifi
Adding WiFi is something different
You can have WiFi without it being attached to your car's controls
I know what you mean, what i’m saying is that it’s a buzzword
the car is the ultimate IoT device
2 tons of steel and aluminum accessible via a smartphone app
Well ya bad developers
Nah dude…
much more complicated than that
there’s no set standard for IoT
kind of a wild west right now
^ there’s that
and writing software for heavy equipment is not as straight forward as consumer stuff
<@U08GFT5V5>: yes that is true. But you're targeting consumers with the IoT stuff. I don't see what those links have anything to do with not being able to secure it properly.
In the first place having access to the steering wheel is bad enough.
Dude, big picture
Does the IoT stuff need access to the steering wheel, the spoilers....?
Bullshit, no big picture here
… :confused:
modern cars are drive-by-wire
lots of sub systems that need to talk to each other
Yes
But does the IoT stuff need to talk to the steering wheel? No.
depends on the device, a lot of comms is routed through the main entertainment system
Then why does the entertainment stuff have access to the steering wheel in the first place?
I can see that the steering wheel can be an input
I can't see why the steering wheel would need to be controlled
automated parking
That is not entertainment
It should allow for it to switch to an automatic parking mode
it is quite entertaining the first time :smile:
Not take control of the steering wheel
The actual logic should be somewhere else then
<@U061HDV96>: Your question sounds like the hardware equivalent of this
<http://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/tasks.png>
That is something totally different
It makes total sense, but when you are involved in the process you can see how it would happen
id imagine the cost to do it would make it not commercially viable
<@U04U5KS3Z>: "being somewhere else" doesn't need to mean physically.
but it may involve say having isolated sub systems
I disagree that this shouldn't be viewed like consumer devices
It totally should
shit I can set the volume of my turn signal clicking through the infotainment :smile:
i agree with you in theory
I disagree…
It’s like saying an aircraft is a consumer device because it has in flight entertainment
You buy a car like you buy a phone
You get it for its features and constant use, not a 1-time thing
You have over 50 mcu’s inside of the car working together to do stuff, these things all have to be hardened to prevent intrusion
If even 1 of them fails, people die
Yes and I feel that you're saying that the lives of people shouldn't be put before their entertainment?
So in this case, finding security vulnerabilites when trying to shoehorn a smartphone on to the dash is not surprising
you find holes in smartphones every week
"Holes" in a smartphone is different
if the arm chip carrying Android/iOS is the weak link, it’s not exactly the manufacturer’s fault
You need constant access to all of the aspects
You do not need access to the steering wheel in a car for example
So trying to treat this like yet another consumer electronics device is trying to solve the wrong problem
Looking at the chip is ridiculous
That argument can be used anywhere without much impact
Look, at the end of the day, the driver of the vehicle is both the pilot, and the passenger
These systems need to talk to each other in order to give the user the features that they need
you are saying this like securing a system is an easy task :smile:
I don't see a single reason why access to the steering wheel or other systems is needed
and "just don't connect it" is not an answer
Securing and denying access is something entirely different
you're implying one follows the other
Follows?
+from
sigh… do you really think that they just plug the steering wheel directly into the phone?
also, who said the steering wheel is accessible from the infotainment? :open_mouth:
It is definitely accessible in some way
[Citation needed]
[Googling, brb]
<http://www.wired.com/2015/07/hackers-remotely-kill-jeep-highway/all/1>

attachments.title: Hackers Remotely Kill a Jeep on the Highway—With Me in It
attachments.text: I was driving 70 mph on the edge of downtown St. Louis when the exploit began to take hold.
attachments.fallback: WIRED: Hackers Remotely Kill a Jeep on the Highway—With Me in It

text: I remember sitting through this lecture where some dude found some holes in some PLCs that were used in some commercial finger print scanners
Sad thing is that they were some really popular chips
Getting the manufacturer to do a recall on those things is basically asking them to flush millions down the toilet
so those chips now sit in big businesses, cannot be updated, and will remain that way for years until they are replaced :confused:
i guess even if you controlled the entire supply chain, it’s still a daunting task to ensure all links in that chain will be secure

<@U061HDV96>: 
> First, they plan to leave out the part of the attack that rewrites the chip’s firmware;
<@U08GFT5V5>: I'm watching their Black hat talk
You know, if I only make this chip less secure, we can hack it
This sh*t is scary though…
but if only you guys knew what I know about airplanes :airplane_departure: :airplane: :airplane_arriving:  :joy:
i read an article not long ago about how insecure the electric grid/water supply is
in the US
scary shit
I know someone on Freenode that is a pilot
He said it's really scary
didnt someone manage to get in to the aircraft systems via the entertainment unit?
<@U04U5KS3Z>: Was a hoax
:eggplant: on my face
Let's just hope no hackers become terrorists
They're still script kiddies
In flight entertainment is on a separate network from the rest of the stuff
But touching on the remote car stuff one last time: it's ridiculous that you can even telnet into a car
^ we are in agreement there
but as someone involved in this stuff… I get it
It’s not easy stuff
Still "I get it" is not enough
I can only ssh into mine :smile:
so points for that
Wait… that means that It has a static IP right?
why would it need to?
I wonder if I can run a webserver off one… :thinking_face:
my infotainment runs linux with a JS/HTML frontend
so you can put what you want on it
but I'm not gonna touch it :smile:
Wait… are you hacking your car?
bricked my TV once while tinkering so nope nope
oh man…don’t stop there
:troll:
we gotta go…deeper
it's all documented out there
car ROMs
paranoid cardroid
give me your ssh credentials
I’ll try installing apache
well, I had to reverse the firmware zip password from the security lib to poke around, but that was just because curious
someone made an SDK
Your car can host <http://androidchat.co|androidchat.co>
well there is the OpenCar SDK too
There’s opencar design models…
so unsurprising
<@U04TK850N>: You’re driving around a potential host for a vps
but there is a third party SDK too: <https://github.com/flyandi/mazda-custom-application-sdk>

text: Well i know what i’m buying…
can already see someone making a piratebay server in a self driving car and letting it loose
tor over car
lol
Man I love our time, we have an sdk… for a car
Someone tweet @internetofshit
marvelous
I tried connecting the car to my home wifi but failed entereing the password once and got annoyed at the fact the german keyboard doesn't have '*'
:joy:
/gif what a time to be alive
